scenes.title: Welcome to vZome
scenes.content:
To introduce you to vZome, we are going to go through the steps to build a simple dodecahedron.  To do this, you won't be editing this document that you're reading.  Use the "New Model..." command from the "File" menu to create a new document where you will build your dodecahedron.  You will want to switch back and forth between reading the pages of this article, and performing the instructions in your dodecahedron model document.

Now proceed to the next page of this article, by clicking on the 2nd thumbnail to the left.  (The thumbnail images may not fill in, sorry.)

As you continue to navigate through these pages, remember that all subsequent instructions here should be performed in your new dodecahedron document.

Also, notice that the main view in this article is not just an image; you can drag your mouse to rotate the 3d model, and use your scroll wheel to zoom in and out.

scenes.title: the starting ball
scenes.content:
Every new vZome document starts with nothing but a single ball.  Your first step will be to make a yellow strut.  Start by setting the strut direction to yellow, by clicking on the yellow circle in the "strut directions" triangle on the right side of your other window.  If the yellow direction was already selected (with a black dot), you'll have to click twice, so the yellow dot has a circle around it.

Next, click on the checkbox labeled "single", just above the direction triangle.  This means you will only build yellow struts.

Next, click on the "y2" button in the "strut size" panel below the triangle.

To actually build the strut, move the mouse cursor over the ball, and click and drag to begin creating a yellow medium strut in any direction.  As you drag the mouse around, the preview strut moves as if it were embedded in a transparent trackball.  You will find the motion easiest to manage if you keep the strut pointing more or less out of the screen toward you.

When you let go of the mouse drag, the transparent preview strut will become a "real" virtual strut.

scenes.title: yellow scaffolding
scenes.content:
The strut you just built is "scaffolding", a temporary structure to support what we really want to build.  We'll remove it before we're done.

Now, click once on the new ball at the end of the yellow strut.  This will select the ball, and it will be highlighted.

scenes.title: icosahedral symmetry
scenes.content:
Most vZome model manipulation commands require a selection of some sort.

With this ball selected, use the "icosahedral around origin" symmetry tool, the first button in the third section of the lower toolbar at the top of the editor window.

scenes.title: twenty balls
scenes.content:
Since you had a ball selected that lies on a threefold symmetry axis, you now see twenty balls.  You can see that these form the vertices of a dodecahedron.

To create an edge of the dodecahedron, you need to select only two balls.  First, deselect everything by clicking on the background.

Then, click on two balls that would form the endpoints of an edge... two balls that are as close as possible to each other.

scenes.title: edge endpoints
scenes.content: With two balls thus selected, you can apply any of the "Connect balls..." tools, the first four in second section of the lower toolbar.

scenes.title: edge strut
scenes.content: The newly created edge strut remains selected after you applied the tool, so you are immediately ready to apply icosahedral symmetry again.

scenes.title: thirty edges
scenes.content: Having created all the dodecahedron's edges, you can guess that the next action is to deselect everything by clicking again on the background.

scenes.title: removing the scaffolding
scenes.content: Now select the original ball and the yellow scaffolding strut, and apply the "delete" tool, the very first button in the toolbar, showing a big red X.

scenes.title: enjoy your dodecahedron
scenes.content: You are now ready to start your vZome journey!
